context.speaker: Abram Chayes
context.text: It says that where denaturalization is imposed as a punishment, and this Court will determine in each particular statutory provision whether it is imposed as a punishment or not.

context.speaker: Abram Chayes
context.text: Where it's imposed as a punishment, it requires a jury trial; where it's imposed for something else, it doesn't require a jury trial.

context.speaker: Abram Chayes
context.text: And I submit those --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: In the case to which you refer Mr. Justice Goldberg wrote --

context.speaker: Abram Chayes
context.text: Wrote the opinion in the Mendoza case I think.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Did he -- did it hold that, I forget.

context.speaker: Bertrand De Blanc
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Bertrand De Blanc
context.text: Now he has never --
(Inaudible)

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You mind furnishing as the memorandum as to an answer to Justice Black's question please as to whether there is any remedy open to him in Louisiana at the present moment?

context.speaker: Bertrand De Blanc
context.text: I'll be very happy to do that Your Honor, I'll be very happy to do that.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Thank you.

Aro Manufacturing Company, Inc. v. Conve.speaker: Justice Black
Aro Manufacturing Company, Inc. v. Conve.case_name: Aro Manufacturing Company, Inc. v. Convertible Top Replacement Company, Inc.
Aro Manufacturing Company, Inc. v. Conve.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 17, 1964

context.speaker: Elliott I. Pollock
context.text: We are -- we are assuming that some act of repair was made at this time intentionally.

context.speaker: Elliott I. Pollock
context.text: I -- I would agree with you entirely, Mr. Justice Black, but if he had done nothing and had merely continued using this car with its dirty top, if you will, that is merely a continuation of the original direct infringement.

context.speaker: Elliott I. Pollock
context.text: It is a continuation of the infringing use which, itself, is direct infringement.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, what do you do with last sentence of Justice Whittaker's opinion?

context.speaker: Elliott I. Pollock
context.text: If I may look at it, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What it says is “measured by this test of replacement of the fabrics involved in this case must be characterized as permissible repair, not reconstruction.”

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: What -- now --

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: What then --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- now, we're getting right back to what I asked you.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You said -- I understood you to say to Justice Clark that -- that no one would object to say that's -- support the Constitution and laws of the United States.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I thought you just told me that you didn't agree to that.

context.speaker: Arval A. Morris
context.text: The position I have to maintain here, with respect to Professor Valentine, is that he will take the oath and support the Constitution.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, the -- does any of your argument, I have listened to it, I don't understand it though, is any of your argument based on the idea that in this country, a man is not required to obey either the Constitution or the laws if he doesn't like them and thinks they are bad?

context.speaker: Arval A. Morris
context.text: No, we would -- that is not our argument in any sense of the term.

context.speaker: Arval A. Morris
context.text: In fact, I would argue to the contrary.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Morris, with reference to Justice Black' question however, you challenge against the word "support" (Inaudible) contrary to Article VI of the Constitution.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The Constitution requires that all Executive and Judicial Officers of the United States and the federal states shall be bound by those affirmations to support this Constitution.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: This is a mandatory provision of the Constitution, its binding upon the officers of the State of Washington by virtue --

Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino.speaker: Justice Brennan
Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino.case_name: Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino
Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 23, 1963

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: In Mann against Petrolera, which is quoted in my brief, and it said that if there -- they were discussing, at that point, property which was located in New York and, therefore, under New York -- well-established New York law, it was not affected by the expropriation decree.

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: But, the court said "if this property had ever been in Cuba, it would have been nationalized even though, later, were brought to the United States" and it said the usual formulation is here, Sabbatino.

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: And -- so, the court -- courts in New York, at least insofar as we have any decisions in New York on this question, disapprove of the Sabbatino case.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, Mr. Rabinowitz, on Mr. Justice White's hypothetical, how short of making the Act of State Doctrine a question of separation of powers and, therefore, the question of federal constitutional law?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Can the federal courts reach the decision in the New York courts?

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: Well, it would be -- it would be difficult.

Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino.speaker: Justice Brennan
Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino.case_name: Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino
Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 22, 1963 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: I should think so.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: I would so argue.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, what Justice Clark has been suggesting is if we can't reach the defense, why shouldn't the Court throw the case out?

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: Well, because the Courts haven't thrown the whole case out in similar situations in United States against Pink, in United States against Belmont, in the Court of Appeals in the Pons case.

context.speaker: Victor Rabinowitz
context.text: The Court proceeded, made no distinction between whether the expropriating government for the nationalizing government was a plaintiff for the defendant, and I think that the brief of the United States handles this question quite well, that this is purely a matter of accident in how the case happens to come before the Court.

context.speaker: Bernard B. Polak
context.text: That is a separate point.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Bernard B. Polak
context.text: There is one --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And your other argument is that the actual entry of the fine under the judgment record, however that was done as Justice Goldberg just discussed with you, on the 25th, starts -- the time running from the 25th so again, you're filing another suit here on May 6 for the time, that --

context.speaker: Bernard B. Polak
context.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Bernard B. Polak
context.text: There are two separate facets of my argument.

context.speaker: Norton J. Come
context.text: We submit, briefly that the Fifth Circuit was erroneous, that the statutory review provision of the National Labor Relations Act submit a -- provides an adequate way by which Greyhound could have had its contentions reviewed and it was Congress' intention that that would be the exclusive procedure by which those contentions could be reviewed.

context.speaker: Norton J. Come
context.text: And as I mentioned before, that the exception recognized in Leedom against Kyne is not applicable here.

context.speaker: Norton J. Come
context.text: Now let --

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Come, in reference to Justice Harlan's question, how can they declare the answer if the merits of the case are not before us?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The whole case as the District Court asserting its jurisdiction (Inaudible) that the employees in question were not employed by Greyhound, isn't that what this case involves?

context.speaker: Norton J. Come
context.text: Well, Your Honor --

Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.speaker: Justice Stewart
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.case_name: Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virginia ex rel. Virginia State Bar
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 13, 1964 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: There are two witnesses who testified in this case and the wife testified and said, “They told us we could take Legal Counsel if we wanted to or we could get our own counsel.”

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: That's in the record by evidence adduced by the respondent.

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: We take the position that the Brotherhood and its members are the same.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In answer to Justice Harlan's question I gathered from your summary of what those witnesses said that the Brotherhood at least takes that much initiative.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: They tell the injured man that he can get -- he can get one of the lawyers you recommend or a lawyer of his own choice and don't they all further advice him not to settle without a lawyer?

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: We tell him exactly --

Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.speaker: Justice Brennan
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.case_name: Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virginia ex rel. Virginia State Bar
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 13, 1964 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: There's nothing malicious about that at all.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: May I ask, Mr. Stallard.

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: Yes?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: To get back to Mr. Justice Harlan's question, do I understand you to say that in each local, perhaps that's not the proper description for the Brotherhood if you know what I mean that there is someone who -- if there is an accident involving a member of the union has a duty to go see him?

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: The constitution, Section 20 -- 91 provides, in every accident, the secretary of the lodge is supposed to make a written report of that accident.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: So that's -- as part of that then is in his duty to go see the injured member?

Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.speaker: Justice Brennan
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.case_name: Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virginia ex rel. Virginia State Bar
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 13, 1964 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: It's his duty under the constitution.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: To see him.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Alright.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, when he goes to see him, I gather what you've answered to Justice Harlan that what he ordinarily tells him is, "You better get yourself a lawyer."

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Is there any service that the Legal Aid Department renders that legal advice may be given by a lawyer other than one retained by the member?

Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.speaker: Justice Stewart
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.case_name: Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virginia ex rel. Virginia State Bar
Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Virg.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 13, 1964 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: That's printed in the directory.

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: There's a general printing in the directory and he calls their attention to those capable lawyers.

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: Now, take Virginia in 1955 --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But as Mr. Justice Brennan has suggested in --

context.speaker: Beecher E. Stallard
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- in Virginia there's just -- there's one lawyer in that region isn't there?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But do you have any -- any resolutions of your -- of your Board of Education or -- or any documents of any kind that would establish this new policy that you're talking about but which neither counsel nor ourselves seem to know anything about?

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: The official records and minutes of the Board of Education would contain that portion of this argument that we're talking about which concerned those applicants in 1963 who had been turned down on the testing criteria, who were called back in and told that they could go to the school of their choice if they live closer to it.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But do we have documents that will -- will answer the precise question that -- that Mr. Justice Brennan asked -- asked of you --

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: I don't --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- about the right of -- right of the colored youngster?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- about the right of -- right of the colored youngster?

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: No, sir, I do not think we do have precise document.

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: I might suggest this Your Honor that --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now, may I ask you this then, do you have any documents that -- that will establish your answer to -- to the question of Justice Goldberg about youngsters who do go to school under those circumstances?

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: No, sir, I don't think there's anything in the record.

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: Now, we could probably --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Did you ever -- did you ever tell counsel for the other side what the plan is?

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: Well, Your Honor, we have it on our brief in the State of Georgia filed the brief of amicus in which they state that the plan now is choice of a space and proximity.

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: He stated I think --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Could you read us that portion of your -- of your brief which will -- will give the answer to Justice Brennan's question?

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: I'll be looking for them if you will.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: Otherwise, if you -- you would have started out with the bad situation and you perpetuate it, that -- that's the point as I see it, yes sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Latimer, may I -- may I just restate Mr. Justice Brennan's question and ask another one whether -- where the -- the Negro child lives in close proximity to an extremely overcrowded Negro school and he wants to go to -- to a white school which is under populated --

context.speaker: A. C. Latimer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- even though he's willing -- his parents are willing to -- to undergo the -- the discomfort of additional travel and he goes over there and applies for admission to that school, what criteria must he meet in making that transfer?
You don't know about the other states?

context.speaker: Calvin H. Childress
context.text: On -- only there is a -- as I recall, in the eavesdroppers, I believe there is a compilation of states there.I -- I have not made a -- a collection on it.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In this case, you need not go quite so far as you indicated.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You -- your position was an answer to Mr. Justice Harlan's question.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Indeed, you in other words, this case doesn't involve a -- an electronic device concealed on the person of somebody who is lawfully in the Constitution -- what the area which would otherwise be constitutionally protected at least such as On Lee or Lopez.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This doesn't --

context.speaker: Calvin H. Childress
context.text: And that this was under the Silverman decision and unreasonable search and seizure.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Did the counsel tell the Court what happened (Inaudible) it was?

context.speaker: Calvin H. Childress
context.text: Neither -- as I understand it, neither counsel on appeal had ever seen the device.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Silverman case, as Mr. Justice Clark have suggested, we -- counsel had in -- here in this courtroom, the actual device.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I have in my office (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I remember 12.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, Mr. Childress, at 31, which it refers to says spike device, just a small device.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This spike device, in any sense, a work of art in this business?

context.speaker: Calvin H. Childress
context.text: If -- if they show at hand definition that is attached to this microphone, I believe the Silverman case, both of a spike device.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well as Mr. Justice Stewart said, we have the actual device and run along -- well, I don't know how long it was.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: There was a spike obviously been used to a circuit.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The device at the end of it was a -- was a hearing device.

Compco Corporation v. Day-Brite Lighting.speaker: Justice Black
Compco Corporation v. Day-Brite Lighting.case_name: Compco Corporation v. Day-Brite Lighting, Inc.
Compco Corporation v. Day-Brite Lighting.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 16, 1964

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You may be -- maybe wrong to say that a state can't do that but I suppose a state could do it the same whether they had applied for a patent or haven't applied for a patent.

context.speaker: Jerome F. Fallon
context.text: Let's see if I get your question, Mr. Justice Black, that --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But what I get is -- what's -- what I'm talking about is this.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: We must assume, as I understand what Mr. Justice Stewart was asking, in Illinois law, they say that it's illegal and you'd get damages.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Companies that have been manufacturing a certain kind of a -- well, anything, say, if you said chair, something else.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I call it a chair.

context.speaker: James P. Donovan
context.text: Yes, because I would've been in jeopardy.

context.speaker: James P. Donovan
context.text: I couldn't -- I couldn't go forward.

context.speaker: James P. Donovan
context.text: I did appeal but I was -- I was threatened with jail if I didn't stop.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: So even if Judge Hughes had done what Mr. Justice White suggest that she might have done, that is to say, "I know you're under a writ of prohibition but nonetheless, it's the federal court, you have a right to be here.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: As far as I'm concerned, I'm going to decide on the merits and I decide its res judicata and therefore, dismiss your complaint," then you still would have been in the same suit so to speak if -- because you would have been prevented from taking your appeal and required to dismiss your appeal under the threat and impact of the contempt order by the Texas state courts, is that it?

context.speaker: James P. Donovan
context.text: I would have been in exactly the same position.

context.speaker: Howard W. Dixon
context.text: Jurisdiction --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- of the persons and subjects matter, is that all?

context.speaker: Howard W. Dixon
context.text: Yes, sir, an essential requirement.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, then it can't be such as Mr. Justice Black just suggested to the Alabama files, where you can get a review whether the decision below is contrary to state law has state as the Supreme Court has announced it.

context.speaker: Howard W. Dixon
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Howard W. Dixon
context.text: I don't think it could be that.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- (Voice Overlap) all that.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Gentlemen -- I beg your pardon.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Wait a minute, may I ask you if there's been any labor decision, and that is the State versus Smith, which your adversary cited to us in which I now have before, citing out what kind of rights can be taken up as of 1960.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: And it very much follows the rule in Alabama to which I refer in which it says, "And we resist the rule wherein they have -- they can bring (Inaudible) with the issue with the Court's discretion to correct the procedural court wherein they have not observed," as Justice Brennan read, "those requirements of the law which are deem to be essential to the Administration of justice."

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Then he says, “Failure to observe the essential requirements of the law means failure to accord due process of law within the contemplation of the Constitution are the commission of -- and error so fundamental in character is to fatally infect the judgment and render it void."

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Then he says, "It seems to be the southern law of the State that the duty of a court to apply, to admitted facts a correct principle of law, correct principle of law is such a fundamental and essential element of the judicial process that a litigant cannot be said to have the remedy and by due process of law guaranteed by Section 4 of the Declaration of Rights."

context.speaker: Edward J. Hill
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: That -- is this the law that you referred to here?

context.speaker: Edward J. Hill
context.text: That statute says --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But that's the one that I think Mr. Justice Harlan's question, if I'm not mistaken, pointed out.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: It finally get down to the point that the only trouble that was because would be by the exercise of a constitutional right under that (Inaudible) law just that -- suppose -- suppose a man which in the end, he belong to a sect and the others didn't like it, they were so much against it as frequently the case that they fight about it if somebody's there (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Edward J. Hill
context.text: Well, I --

context.speaker: Robert A. Brown
context.text: And if --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: (Voice Overlap) -- but you are through when you get --

context.speaker: Robert A. Brown
context.text: Sir?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: -- I want to ask you about Justice Harlan's question --

context.speaker: Robert A. Brown
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: -- I do not see how, if I understand the record correctly, your answer could possibly be correct.

context.speaker: Richard F. Generelly
context.text: We complained because we said, "Suppose you later find 20 at the conclusion of this hearing on the permanent, and incidentally, you know they don't at anything at a permanent, they don't look at any of this evidence on anymore."

context.speaker: Richard F. Generelly
context.text: "In case you do, we're out of luck, but alright, in the alternative, let us then proceed under Section 4," and either case we agreed to refund it.

context.speaker: Richard F. Generelly
context.text: Now, as to the future --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: (Inaudible) but Justice Goldberg -- and as I understood CATCO, when they heard and held at 1970, I believe it was, gave the right to attach conditions and that they could investigate and fix the rate below that which was clear and you --

context.speaker: Richard F. Generelly
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: -- had accepted that.

context.speaker: Frank B. Parsons
context.text: I think it's more general law, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, but specifically, state law and not federal law --

context.speaker: Frank B. Parsons
context.text: Well, I think its federal law, too, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- in answer to Justice Harlan's question.

context.speaker: Frank B. Parsons
context.text: I mean it's -- it's not -- it's not a statute.

context.speaker: Frank B. Parsons
context.text: It's not a -- it's common law, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Donald K. Barnes
context.text: When we split the Portland Chevrolet office and put half of it in Seattle, we have since that time paid tax on every transaction going through the Seattle office.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I don't understand why you wouldn't in the way be taken from taxes and given it over to Oregon.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You've said, paid tax on that office, but in reality, it belongs to Washington.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: I think you've misunderstood Justice Black's question.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: You gave the number of people employed in Washington.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: He asked the number of people employed in Oregon.

context.speaker: John W. Riley
context.text: And (c) is the burden of a tax disproportionate to the benefits conferred by the State?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: That's what I was saying.

context.speaker: John W. Riley
context.text: In that order.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But Mr. Riley, I take back Mr. Justice White's question to you.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Missouri may impose a tax on manufacturer measured by the amount of the wholesale.

context.speaker: John W. Riley
context.text: No, measured --

Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner.speaker: Justice Black
Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner.case_name: Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner
Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 04, 1964

context.speaker: Ferdinand A. Cashio
context.text: It has them --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Has not.

context.speaker: Ferdinand A. Cashio
context.text: It has not?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I understood you to say that, unless the State has reserved the right to tax of the condition, as I understood you are reading from Mr. Justice Douglas' opinion in the original case.

context.speaker: Ferdinand A. Cashio
context.text: I don't understand that from the opinion, Mr. Justice Black.

context.speaker: Ferdinand A. Cashio
context.text: If I may go back --

Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner.speaker: Justice Black
Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner.case_name: Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner
Humble Pipe Line Co. v. Waggonner.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 04, 1964

context.speaker: Ferdinand A. Cashio
context.text: Because as I have heretofore pointed out and as stated in our brief, the Federal Government in -- in leasing this land, has expressed an intent.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You're putting it -- you're putting it then on something that happened afterwards.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You're putting after -- you -- you take the position that the lease is likely a conditional sale and that -- and the case to which Justice -- Mr. Justice Reed wrote?

context.speaker: Ferdinand A. Cashio
context.text: Right, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: That's your argument there but --

context.speaker: Attorney
context.text: Well -- no, I say several things --

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: You say --

context.speaker: Attorney
context.text: -- that they --

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Do you say I guess it -- you're -- you're talking -- you're using fraud in a different way than Justice Black, I gather it is?

context.speaker: Attorney
context.text: Well I -- I think so.

context.speaker: Attorney
context.text: On the first place I say that they have no right on this kind of a matter to demand that the union be an advocate of their views.

context.speaker: William I. Siegel
context.text: After --

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: William I. Siegel
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: And Justice Jackson says I think under New York law, page 162, New York law says it requires a preliminary hearing of admissibility.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: I thought you said it was discretionary.

context.speaker: William I. Siegel
context.text: Well, if the point is raised.

context.speaker: William I. Siegel
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- you where that confession is, that second confession is in the record at, do you recall?
Page 10.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Oh, (Inaudible) -- Mr. Justice Harlan just told me its page 10, it's alright.

context.speaker: William I. Siegel
context.text: Yes, sir, that's at page 10.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes.

John Wiley & Sons, Inc. v. Livingston.speaker: Justice White

John Wiley & Sons, Inc. v. Livingston.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 13, 1964

context.speaker: Thomas E. Harris
context.text: Well, if the old unit survived and the contract survived for some period of time after October 2, then the union is entitled to arbitrate as to what its rights under that contract or what the rights of the employees under that contract are.

context.speaker: Thomas E. Harris
context.text: That would be true even if the arbitration had not been brought and then after the contract run out which was indeed the situation in American manufacturer.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Then it was true here.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: By the time you asked -- have you asked arbitration before the contract expired but after on Mr. Justice Brennan's --

context.speaker: Thomas E. Harris
context.text: But the union --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: -- hypothesis there was a dissolution of the bargaining agreement.

John Wiley & Sons, Inc. v. Livingston.speaker: Justice White
John Wiley & Sons, Inc. v. Livingston.case_name: John Wiley & Sons, Inc. v. Livingston

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Charles H. Lieb
context.text: Yes, he did it as against Interscience.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, I understand that.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But he -- but Justice Brennan said assuming Wiley is the step of the arbitration clause too.

context.speaker: Charles H. Lieb
context.text: Yes, but if you look at -- at what Judge Kaufman said.

context.speaker: Charles H. Lieb
context.text: And he says at a little bit more concisely on page 110, he says “We hold that the bargaining agreement does not clearly remove from the scope of arbitration the following questions, whether the collective bargaining agreement, as a whole, survived the consolidation.”

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I gather, as I understood, you've got the counterclaim (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Alfred L. Scanlan, Jr.
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Regardless that this is the same question as I think Justice Goldberg asked you that (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Alfred L. Scanlan, Jr.
context.text: Well, we're faced with the one problem, whether the Court -- suppose the arbitrator comes up with the finding that these walkouts were justified and these men should be taken back and be p -- back-wages paid to the date of the walkout and, on the other hand, the Supreme Court of Iowa pulls a trial court or a jury finding perhaps that the employer suffered a 150,000 damages because of the shrinkage of the cattle in the yards during the period of the strike.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What if --

Maryland Committee for Fair Representati.speaker: Justice Clark
Maryland Committee for Fair Representati.case_name: Maryland Committee for Fair Representation v. Tawes
Maryland Committee for Fair Representati.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 14, 1963 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: But it's the same principle?

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Your Senate is anchored to one per county except in both --

context.speaker: Robert S. Bourbon
context.text: That's right, that's right.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: And your House is anchored to two to a county, now, Justice White's question is whether or not, is that as the Solicitor General claims, fails to meet the requirements of the Fourteenth Amendment as to the House, with reference to it, being population wise when it's anchored to two to a county?

context.speaker: Robert S. Bourbon
context.text: Well all I can say in this, I think if the Court will go back, I think, again I'm looking to history but I think the history of this thing is that from the beginning of the founding of the State, that in so far as population is concerned, that they gave a minimum to each of the counties.

context.speaker: Robert S. Bourbon
context.text: This -- this I think from 1776, that insofar as you're talking about a reasonable state policy of doing this, that this complies at least, it's been consistent.

context.speaker: Joseph Kovner
context.text: I think that marshaling -- the -- let me put it this way.

context.speaker: Joseph Kovner
context.text: The private creditor in the case given would have had the benefit of the marshaling doctrine but-for a state exemption statute.

context.speaker: Joseph Kovner
context.text: That state exemption statute does not apply to the United States and therefore, the marshaling doctrine can be ignored.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I know, but except in Mr. Justice Goldberg's hypothetically case, the -- the debtor had voluntarily agreed by contract that the proceeds, the entire proceeds to the life insurance policy would be available to the first creditor.

context.speaker: Joseph Kovner
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And therefore, the statute has been waived, has it not?

Missouri Pacific R. Company v. Elmore &.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 03, 1964

context.speaker: John C. North, Jr.
context.text: We do not have a final record here, yet the man who was testifying about it was the one that made up and says that the funds ought to be owned and he was on the -- the committee, tariff committee and everything and then they asked him, "Why didn't they have a record?"

context.speaker: John C. North, Jr.
context.text: He says, "We didn't like a rule that required us to keep one."

context.speaker: John C. North, Jr.
context.text: They were very smart about that but they didn't keep one whether it's required or not.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, may I ask you (Inaudible) Mr. Justice Black's question, as I understand your position is, you make the case for liability, merely on proof of loading in good shape, arriving in poor shape.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The railroad then has to prove two things.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It has to prove absence of negligence but that doesn't let it out unless it also proves what?

National Association for the Advancement.speaker: Justice Black
National Association for the Advancement.case_name: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People v. Alabama ex rel. Flowers
National Association for the Advancement.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1964 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: He overruled a motion for rehearing?

context.speaker: Gordon Madison
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But he passed it.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Now, the court of -- the Supreme Court has not passed on it you say as I -- I understood you to say that in response to Justice White, suppose they haven't then we must look to the judgment from that point if the court -- Circuit Court is being the highest court in which the question could be decided.

context.speaker: Gordon Madison
context.text: I -- I certainly cannot answer that for simple reason, I don't know.

context.speaker: Gordon Madison
context.text: I say this that I was on the impression and still on the impression and as you find that the Supreme Court of Alabama has applied some of its rules or procedures and practice which it should not have that it did on it in an arbitrary or in a reasonable manner to this petitioner that you --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I -- That's my trouble.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: By picketing --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Marching and patrolling with a placard.

Polar Ice Cream & Creamery Company v. An.speaker: Justice Black
Polar Ice Cream & Creamery Company v. An.case_name: Polar Ice Cream & Creamery Company v. Andrews
Polar Ice Cream & Creamery Company v. An.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 20, 1963 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Johnson S. Savary
context.text: Every drop and the State of New York said, “We will not give you a license and be illegal for you to sell this milk in New York unless you pay Vermont the same thing you have to pay for New York milk.”

context.speaker: Johnson S. Savary
context.text: And as I understood --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I don't quite get your difference.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The sentence to which Justice Douglas declared to your case in 186 had not, do the regulation, restrict plaintiff from purchasing out-of-state milk in any amount or for any price.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I understand you say that is to rest but it does keep him from selling.

context.speaker: Johnson S. Savary
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Sidney M. Glazer
context.text: Three men in the other car, three men and this town has a police force, according to FBI, a uniform crime reports 60, 60 or 61 police and police employees, total police force.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: What I was -- are you through?

context.speaker: Sidney M. Glazer
context.text: Yeah.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: It appeared to me that the Court could get avoid the doubts of Justice Goldberg if they adopted Mr. Shea's doubts as to the search of the automobile, what is your answer to that?

context.speaker: Sidney M. Glazer
context.text: Specifically whether or not you could just search the automobile, the delayed search your Honor.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: When they found the guns and charged them with the -- having the guns.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Seems to me like your weakness, main weakness in your case is the fact that they took it back up to this place and probably kept there waiting and they just decided they wanted to look and see if they could find something, they didn't know what.

context.speaker: Sidney M. Glazer
context.text: Well of course, it seems to me if you have a case where it's clear that's the police officers can search not only for weapons to -- suppose you have a situation when somebody is driving a car and there is probable cause to believe the car contains liquor, and as Carroll, specific Carroll type of situation, the police officers instead of searching the car at scene take the car with the man to the police garage and conduct the search.

context.speaker: Sidney M. Glazer
context.text: It seems to me that if they have a right to search not only for weapons but for --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: (Inaudible) car and then when they -- in the case vagrancy, you don't suspect them of doing anything but loitering as Justice Black says, or if you're really left with just the safety factor?

context.speaker: Sidney M. Glazer
context.text: Well I don't think -- I think you are loitering, you just can't look at loitering, loitering certainly has a safety factor and it's true that this Court has said that generally speaking a search --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Are you suggesting that you can arrest someone for loitering and automatically you are entitled to suspect that he is going to commit a crime?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But you can't say here very well that they were just searching at that compartment to see if everything was all right and then let him go on their way, because you had already booked him and put him in jail or put all these men in jail.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: So, if you had done that perhaps at the scene of the arrest, it might have been one thing, but here you have closed that door.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You have taken his car in possession, the police officer drove it from the city street where it had a right to be down to the police department, put it in the lot, put them in jail and lock them up and then after that they go and search the car.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now I understood you did say in response to Mr. Justice Clark's question that if there had been a substantial period of time elapsed between the time that they put these men in jail and the time they went down to search the car that if they would of necessity have to have the search warrant.

context.speaker: Sidney M. Glazer
context.text: Yes that would, it seem to me if there is a substantial time in the lapse and there is certainly absolutely no -- there is no time, there is no time of the essence problem there, they can use the lapsed time to obtain a search warrant.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Where do you draw those limits?

Publishers' Assn. of New York City v. Ma.speaker: Justice White
Publishers' Assn. of New York City v. Ma.case_name: Publishers' Assn. of New York City v. Mailers
Publishers' Assn. of New York City v. Ma.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1964

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- if this is not much different from that.

context.speaker: Sidney Sugerman
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Sidney Sugerman
context.text: I -- but I -- I should think that they're ought -- ought to be and as I have sensed from your cases generally, there has been some threat or likelihood of a revival of the matter or recommission of the Act enjoined complaining that.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The only threat in that -- the only threat of the case Mr. Justice Brennan mentioned was that somebody might change his mind.

context.speaker: Sidney Sugerman
context.text: Well then I don't know what -- how you could ever be sure of mootness.

context.speaker: Sidney Sugerman
context.text: I -- I suppose no matter what were presented to you to satisfy you that the matter was moot conceivably, it might be undone on a showing of fraud and overreaching pressure and so on.

Quantity of Copies of Books v. Kansas.speaker: Justice Warren
Quantity of Copies of Books v. Kansas.case_name: Quantity of Copies of Books v. Kansas
Quantity of Copies of Books v. Kansas.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 02, 1964

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, you have several means of law enforcement and one of them involves very serious constitutional questions and another involves none.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Is it unreasonable for the courts to ask you to combine with the one that does involve constitutional questions, the one that does not in order to protect against the constitutional questions.

context.speaker: William M. Ferguson
context.text: Well Mr. Chief --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: It sees to me that it's just so simple, if you really want to put obscenity out of business, it seems to me so simple to do what Mr. Justice Clark said.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You can get a search warrant and an arrest warrant against the man who is purveying this filth and you can prosecute him and put him in the jail at the same time that your -- you've got an injunction suit pending against him and that if you convict him, you have no problem at all with your injunction and the suit.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You can take all the volumes out of circulation, that way that you could take under this simple short cutting system which you use I suggest because it's easy and the other is a little more difficult.

context.speaker: Stephen J. Pollak
context.text: You just -- you'd have as they said, you've have the same court making the same decision of law.

context.speaker: Stephen J. Pollak
context.text: There would be no -- there would be no irreparable harm.

context.speaker: Stephen J. Pollak
context.text: There would be no question that equity would deny the jurisdiction.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, Mr. Pollak -- Mr. Pollak, you don't answer Justice White if there's basic public policy consideration as relying here, interference for the prosecution of the criminal lawyers in civil actions.

context.speaker: Stephen J. Pollak
context.text: Well, I thought -- I thought I'd already argued that and he was saying I don't accept that but I hope he --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I wouldn't think he was suggesting that.

Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon.speaker: Justice Black
Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon.case_name: Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon
Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 28, 1964

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Your argument is that they did intend to put a man out of business because he -- he was buying and selling different things simply because he transported them himself.

context.speaker: Walter C. Wolff, Jr.
context.text: No, sir but that -- it's necessary to show that there are some sort of prearranged plans, some sort of sham, prearranged plans to -- between the -- the transporter and the ultimate purchaser, so to enable that purchaser to receive transportation at a reduced cost, and that is the exact language that the committee -- the congressional committee has used when the -- they were discussing the passage in the amendment of -- of the Acts pertaining to Section 203 (c).

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You deny that the act of your -- guilt in violation of this depends on how much you bought and sold of one product and how much you bought and sold of another.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: As Justice Brennan said, if your primary business was to buy and sell.

context.speaker: Walter C. Wolff, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir and we also believe that the evidence shows that we do a considerable sugar business in comparison with other businesses, is not a large concern but the -- if sugar operations are on a parity with their other operations.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: These -- do these figures show that you got a -- made it private on this?

Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon.speaker: Justice Stewart
Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon.case_name: Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon
Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc. v. Shannon.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 28, 1964

context.speaker: Walter C. Wolff, Jr.
context.text: That's the first point.

context.speaker: Walter C. Wolff, Jr.
context.text: The second point is we feel that we have -- can show and the facts do show that we are really in the primary business of buying and selling sugar.

context.speaker: Walter C. Wolff, Jr.
context.text: And --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You can be a -- I'm sorry if you're still answering Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I don't want to interrupt you.

context.speaker: Walter C. Wolff, Jr.
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: W. McLean Pitts
context.text: And it dropped down now. This is -- this act that the federal court has got it -- brought it back up to about 41%.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Have we stored the stipulation on what it was --

context.speaker: W. McLean Pitts
context.text: About 3% back and restored it back to the 1901 Constitutional Convention, I mean the Constitution.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Pitts, going back to Justice Harlan's question of -- a moment ago, go into the basic -- basic question before we get to the matter of remedy, the basic question of constitutional violation here as I -- as I understood him, Justice Harlan suggested that the basic argument on -- for you to make was that there was no constitutional violation but as I read the opinion of the three-judge court of July 21st, 1962.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That argument is -- is not open to you unless I misread it or unless the Court here is misstating the fact and I'm quoting from 144 of the record where the Court says, "It has been generally conceded throughout this litigation by all the parties that the present apportionment for both Houses of the legislature of the State of Alabama constitutes invidious discrimination in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Is that factually untrue or is it true?

context.speaker: Vincent A. Theisen
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Vincent A. Theisen
context.text: I think it maybe be shorter.

context.speaker: Vincent A. Theisen
context.text: On occasions, I think it's been overnight.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I just want to (Inaudible) Mr. Justice Brennan would meet your objection (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Vincent A. Theisen
context.text: I would say that it would meet our objections as far as the House is concerned.

context.speaker: Vincent A. Theisen
context.text: It -- as I understand the bill, it divides the State into 45 districts and then divides the number of 45 into the number of population and then allots the different districts according to the number of the popular quotient.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: It was brought into your argument (Inaudible) Equal Protection Clause of the suffrage itself (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Frederick Bernays Wiener
context.text: I -- I'm inclined to think that that follows but I don't go that far.

context.speaker: Frederick Bernays Wiener
context.text: What our position briefly is that having regard to that very fragile foundation, it will not support the burden that was sought to be placed on it by the arguments last month, namely, that the Equal Protection Clause requires both houses of a legislature to be apportioned according to population or that -- and this was actually the holding below that the Equal Protection Clause somehow or rather incorporates the multiplication tables.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Going back to the question asked by Chief Justice Warren, I thought (Inaudible) of the original brief or quite appeared (Inaudible) draft the apportionment according population than (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Frederick Bernays Wiener
context.text: That --

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: (Inaudible) Constitution play the litigation.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But it isn't.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That isn't what happened.

context.speaker: David C. Acheson
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And you're saying -- the question is -- when you answer Mr. Justice Black that you -- that you stand on the face of the affidavit, certainly as it regards the -- if this petitioner had -- had been able to show that the -- that the -- that the agent lied, knowingly lied substantially in the affidavit, I suppose the -- you would conceive that they might be entitled to the name of the informant.

context.speaker: David C. Acheson
context.text: Fairly.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: David C. Acheson
context.text: I -- I think it would be an unconscionable --
As I understand you to say that the inquiry is not to prove that simply because as a matter of constitutional law, it is a probable cause satisfied (Inaudible).

context.speaker: David C. Acheson
context.text: That's right and as a matter of the self-respect of the prosecutor.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In other words, you would not take the act, you would take the situation as Mr. Justice Black is suggesting that some states do but you can't go behind the affidavit that the magistrate acted upon but if the affiant lied in anything he said, you prosecute him for perjury.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But you go beyond that you've -- you've said it, that if you had proved that the affiant lied, that maybe a basis for find -- a holding that probable cause collapsed.

context.speaker: David C. Acheson
context.text: Yes, I think another way of putting it is that we can't -- there can't be a conclusive presumption that the Commissioner is the guarantor of the good faith and the truthfulness of all affiants.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: They don't care whether this person claims to be an American citizen, they know that.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: They claim that the person is still their citizen or has reacquired their citizenship and this is the problem in the 19th Century which is so clear, of two different states asserting jurisdiction over the same person.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: And so --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Perhaps I will ask in regard to Mr. Justice White question, doesn't this act give the Secretary of State most unlimited discretion to determine who can go to -- to the country of his birth and --

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: He doesn't have any discretion Your Honor.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I beg your pardon.

context.speaker: Arlo E. Smith
context.text: Implied permission you are talking about good faith.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In that case the officer got a key from the building (Inaudible) and entered the apartment.

context.speaker: Arlo E. Smith
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Justice Clark's point is why didn't California (Inaudible)?

context.speaker: Arlo E. Smith
context.text: The distinction is I am sorry I -- the distinction is the distinction I have been attempting to make here which is a distinction in Roberts California case and in Chapman.

context.speaker: Arlo E. Smith
context.text: An apartment the right of a landlord and tenant, there is no contention here that these doctrines apply to an apartment.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: The private plaintiff brought the case here.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Justice Black vacated all the stays and on September 13, 1962, the District Court finally entered an injunction in accordance with the mandate of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: The full term that --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Was Mr. Justice Black's order itself in the nature of an injunction?

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: It was in -- it was in the nature of an injunction in addition to vacating the stay, good as I recall up until the District Court had entered the mandate.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: I don't think it's purported to go beyond that point.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: And the District Court decided it for civil contempt.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: And the District Court dismissed the citation.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, it would not have been the order I think that entered in the District Court after Mr. Justice Black's statement.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: On the merits, yes.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: (Inaudible) to your case that I think that will be very easy to find out.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Would you supply us a memorandum to that effect as to -- after your argument as to whether on this date it was unlawful to go to Cuba.

context.speaker: Robert L. Shevin
context.text: Yes sir, I can.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: And the other question that Mr. Justice Clark asked you.

context.speaker: Robert L. Shevin
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You will -- you will --

United States v. Penn-Olin Chemical Comp.speaker: Justice Stewart
United States v. Penn-Olin Chemical Comp.case_name: United States v. Penn-Olin Chemical Company
United States v. Penn-Olin Chemical Comp.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 30, 1964 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: No, I think there has to be -- we -- we say there must be some distinctions here.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: We do say that the distinctions should be based on objective events.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: And my argument with respect to these narrow first objective conditions, I should say, rather than events, my argument on this first narrow point, let me conclude it and then go on, is that this case is essentially the same as the hypothetical illustrations that I have put.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, your hypothetical illustrations all implied a monopolistic situation and as Mr. -- Mr. Justice Goldberg's question revealed, we don't have that in this case as the (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Oh, it seems to me, we -- we don't -- it seems to me that we have, except for my geographical one, at least as narrow as if an -- if not a narrower market.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You mean, if -- if (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Well the -- it has just occurred to me that we might be in somewhat a difficult position because normally, we -- the -- those are the general's offices in the position defending the constitutionality of -- of congressional legislation.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But may I say I have difficulty in this being with Mr. Justice Harlan.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I do not see how you can escape the very question that we're raising.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: If Congress could by itself divide some of the voters of right so that by creating districts, 10,000 for one, 100,000 for another, I do not see why Congress hasn't permitted the state to do that?

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: I -- I would like to point out that there has been a session of the legislature since that time it did not act.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Now, there may be a justification.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: The case after all was on appeal and --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And the court didn't do what Mr. Justice White suggested it might have --

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Well, it said it was arbitrary (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That was -- that was Judge Tuttle's idea was that --

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: The Act must be judged on its own merits.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I thought that was your position here --

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- before you answered Mr. Justice Harlan.

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: Well I -- I, I merely attempted to answer Justice Harlan's question as to whether this or -- this circumstance did or did not appear in the record of those proceedings and to the best of my recollection, it did not.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: I would think that on the most circumstances, a state would have regard to a combination possibly, all of the factors which I have mentioned.

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: But no one stands out predominant, no one subordinates another.

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: It might for example be, you might have a situation of the state relying solely on the population standard, that in itself would not be unconstitutional nor would it be unconstitutional if a state relied let's say on the minimum guarantee of one -- of one representative for the voters of each county.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: As I understand you correct me yesterday to your answer of Mr. Justice Black, if you would (Inaudible) that the other principle of accessibility, quite support the -- the reapportionment in -- in New York City for example, one donor legislative on the ground of New York City with the compact (Inaudible) with voluntary that having one legislator that you have accessed to the legislator who can make (Inaudible) involved in.

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: I had not carried it Mr. Justice Goldberg to that extreme as I recall that I think it was at that point in the argument that I pointed out that there are situations in which concepts reach a breaking point where you can carry a notion to such an extreme that you -- you carry it to almost an absurd indeed to an absurd extent.

context.speaker: Irving Galt
context.text: And while -- we would not go that far, there are these situations of extremes.

context.speaker: Leonard B. Sand
context.text: The legislature may consider all of this and may consider more, but in apportioning representatives on the basis of these criteria, the net result must be a legislature which proportionately represents population.

context.speaker: Leonard B. Sand
context.text: And where it does not, when it does not, then at a minimum, the burden is upon the State to come forth and to say, "We have adopted this method because this method achieves greater representativeness of the legislature.

context.speaker: Leonard B. Sand
context.text: " Now, that is not what New York State had --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, now, let me -- Mr. Justice Harlan has asked you this unsuccessfully and maybe the answer is -- nobody can successfully answer, but where does this rule of law come from that you've just enunciated?

context.speaker: Leonard B. Sand
context.text: I -- I think it -- it comes from the -- from the basic nature of our -- of our system, the -- the genius of our democratic society.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, then --

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: Yes, yes. Yes.
(Inaudible)

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: If it invaded the wife's half of the estate, I would say that there would be a -- a reasonable case for constructive fraud upon the wife, but not until that time.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But Mr. Whitmore I don't -- the answer you gave to the question of Justice White because that's the (Inaudible) --

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: No, I don't --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Because as I understand it, the record doesn't enlighten us whether the bonds -- what he did under the will accomplishes the method to dispose of more than half of the estate.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case?

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: No, it was decided afterwards.

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: However, I think and I would suggest the law of fraud is -- has been --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well that maybe I don't understand you but I thought you answered Mr. Justice White that if -- what he attempted to dispose of by will, plus what he has done with these bonds, together it represents the effort to dispose of more than half of the community than to the extent that it exceeds half that would fall within the exception stated in Free and Bland.

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: Under the facts of the present case, I would say that since it does not appear that there is here an attempt to dispose of more than half of the community estate by will, or by the use of the -- these bonds which we're here concerned with that therefore, there is presently before us no fraud.

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: Now, if upon the final settlement of the case, it should appear that -- and I think that that should be determined -- determinative of the case at this point because --

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: I -- I think -- I -- I view it as the same question.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And -- and not within the exception of fraud?

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: No, because the use of the bonds would not constitute the fraud.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So, I thought that you answered Justice Douglas a while ago that there would be pro tanto.

context.speaker: Ernest R. Whitmore, Jr.
context.text: Yes, only beyond the 50%.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I know but --
